en.title: Technical Analysis Foundations
en.subtitle: Learn to read charts and identify patterns that predict price movements
objectives: Understand the principles of technical analysis
Learn to read basic chart types and timeframes
Identify support and resistance levels on price charts
Recognize the importance of volume in price analysis
en.intro: Technical analysis forms the backbone of most short-term trading strategies. This analytical approach focuses on studying price charts, patterns, and market behavior to predict future movements. Unlike fundamental analysis, technical analysis assumes all relevant information is already reflected in price action.
en.section1_text: Charts are the primary tools for technical analysis, displaying price movements over various timeframes. The most common types include line charts, bar charts, and candlestick charts. Candlestick charts provide the most visual information, showing opening, closing, high, and low prices. Each candlestick displays the price range and direction for that period. Timeframes range from one-minute charts for scalping to monthly charts for long-term analysis.
en.section2_text: Support and resistance levels represent key areas where buying or selling interest emerges. Support levels are prices where buying interest prevents further declines. Resistance levels are areas where selling pressure limits upward movement. These levels can be horizontal lines at specific prices or dynamic levels like moving averages. When prices break through these levels, it often signals significant moves in the breakout direction.
en.section3_text: Volume represents the number of shares or contracts traded during a specific period. Volume analysis helps confirm price movements and identify potential reversals. Price movements accompanied by high volume are considered more significant than those on low volume. Rising prices on increasing volume suggest strong buying interest, while rising prices on declining volume might indicate weakening momentum.
en.section4_text: Trends represent the general direction of price movement over time. Uptrends show higher highs and higher lows, indicating buying pressure. Downtrends display lower highs and lower lows, reflecting selling pressure. Sideways trends occur when prices move within a defined range. Understanding trends across multiple timeframes helps traders make better decisions about trade direction and timing.
en.takeaway1: Technical analysis uses price charts and patterns to predict future movements
en.takeaway2: Candlestick charts provide comprehensive price information for analysis
en.takeaway3: Support and resistance levels help identify key price areas for decisions
en.takeaway4: Volume confirms price movements and reveals market sentiment
en.takeaway5: Trend analysis helps traders align with market direction
en.exercise: Choose a stock or currency pair and identify three support levels and three resistance levels on a daily chart. Mark these levels and observe how prices react when they approach these areas over the next week. Note whether the levels hold or break and what happens to volume during these tests.
